metadata.titleEn: NPP-VIIRS interannual night time light remote sensing dataset for the Sahel-Sudano-Guinean region of Africa (2013-2020)
metadata.description: The data set contains annual NPP-VIIRS night time light data images of equatorial northern Africa and the Sahel region from 2013 to 2020. Based on the monthly average night time light image data of visible infrared imaging radiometer Suite (VIIRS) of national polar orbiting partnership (NPP) satellite, this dataset is generated by separating the unstable night light caused by biomass combustion from the stable night light information caused by human activities. The spatial resolution of the data is 500 m, and the grid data type is GeoTIFF. The grid pixel value is radiance, and the unit is 10 − 9 w ∙ cm − 2 ∙ SR − 1. The data set improves the ability of noctilucent images to identify small-scale, scattered and unstable urban information in northern equatorial Africa and Sahel to a certain extent, and can be further applied to the research on human activities in northern equatorial Africa and Sahel.
metadata.instructions:
File name: the data is stored in GeoTIFF format. The file name is "viirs_annual_yyyy. TIF", where yyyy represents the year.
Data reading method: software or computer language that can read GeoTIFF can read the data, such as ArcGIS, envi, IDL, python, MATLAB, etc.

background: Observing and understanding changes in Africa is a hotspot in global ecological environmental research since the early 1970s. As possible causes of environmental degradation, frequent droughts and human activities attracted wide attention. Remote sensing of nighttime light provides an effective way to map human activities and assess their intensity. Nighttime light is a good indicator of human activity. Satellite-borne imaging radiometers capture accurate nighttime light data, thus providing the opportunity to study the nighttime light quantitatively in large areas. Low power penetration affects the northern Equatorial Africa and Sahel region, where power cuts occur frequently. The electricity deficit is one of the main problems in the development of this region. The visible near-infrared (VNIR) image data acquired by the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program Operational Linescan System (DMSP-OLS) are widely used to capture stable nighttime light. More recent data acquired by the National Polar-orbiting Partnership Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (NPP-VIIRS) were applied for the same purpose. Compared to DMSP-OLS, NPP-VIIRS has the advantages of higher spatial resolution (about 742 m) and on-board calibration, and it is not affected by saturation and has a higher dim light sensitivity. Earlier studies on the detection and characterization of human settlements using nighttime light data relied on the estimation of an optimal threshold on radiance according to reference data, on using ancillary data, and on change detection.
research objective: The aim of this study was to propose a better way to extract information about human activities in northern Equatorial Africa and Sahel from the National Polar-orbiting Partnership Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (NPP-VIIRS) monthly nighttime light data. The objective of this study was to provide a new method (i.e., the patches filtering method, PFM) for filtering NPP-VIIRS monthly nighttime light data to improve the ability to identify small settlements, including small and scattered ones, which required the separation of stable nighttime lights associated with settlements from unstable nighttime lights due to biomass burning.
challenges: The biggest obstacle to obtain images that only retain information about settlements comes from biomass burning. Biomass burning emits light at night, which can be captured by sensors; thus, it cannot be visually distinguished in a direct manner from the light related to settlements in nighttime light data. The biomass burning signal is usually separated from the settlement signal by the “masking” or by the “threshold” filtering method. Since the biomass burning nighttime radiance often exceeds 2 × 10−9 W·cm−2·sr−1, the threshold value must be higher than that. It should be noted that the nighttime light radiance of many small settlements might be less than 2 × 10−9 W·cm−2·sr−1, especially in developing regions; thus, the “threshold” method inevitably filters out useful information on nighttime light related to human settlements. The lower spatial and radiometric resolution of DMSP data limits the application of this method.
methods: In this study, we developed the patches filtering method (i.e., PFM), a new method to separate unstable nighttime light induced by biomass burning from stable nighttime light in NPP-VIIRS monthly nighttime light data. Biomass burning light is separated from settlement light taking into account the relatively short duration of biomass burning events. The method is demonstrated by generating a new 2016 annual image to better capture anthropic information.
dataset: NPP-VIIRS (L1B data product, calibrated top-of-atmosphere radiance) monthly nighttime light data from January 2015 to December 2017 were the main data in this study. The NPP-VIIRS 2016 annual nighttime light image from the NCEI was taken as a reference to evaluate the new annual image and its capability to identify the settlements in the study area. Three auxiliary datasets were applied in this study to evaluate the new annual nighttime light image generated in this study, including the Sentinel-2 prototype Land Cover 20 m 2016 map of Africa released by the European Space Agency (ESA-S2-AFRICA-LC20), the global land-cover and land-use reference data derived from the Geo-Wiki crowdsourcing platform, and high-resolution Google Earth images.
findings: The results show that PFM is useful for improving the quality of NPP-VIIRS monthly nighttime light data. Settlement lights were effectively separated from biomass burning lights, in addition to capturing the seasonality of biomass burning. We show that the new 2016 nighttime light image can very effectively identify even small settlements, notwithstanding their fragmentation and unstable power supply. We found that the new annual nighttime light data performed best among the three datasets in capturing settlements, with a high recognition rate of 61.8%, and absolute superiority for settlements of 2.5 square kilometers or less. This shows that the method separates biomass burning signals very effectively, while retaining the relatively stable, although dim, lights of small settlements. The new 2016 annual image demonstrates good performance in identifying human settlements in sparsely populated areas toward a better understanding of human activities.

Definition.Question: What is the patches filtering method (PFM) used in nighttime light data collection?
Definition.Answer: The patches filtering method (PFM) is a new approach developed to separate unstable nighttime light induced by biomass burning from stable nighttime light in NPP-VIIRS monthly nighttime light data. This method considers the relatively short duration of biomass burning events to distinguish them from settlement lights, thereby improving the ability to identify small and scattered settlements.

Definition.Question: What are the main challenges in separating settlement lights from biomass burning in nighttime light data?
Definition.Answer: The main challenge in separating settlement lights from biomass burning in nighttime light data is that biomass burning emits light at night, which sensors capture alongside the light related to settlements. This makes it difficult to visually distinguish between them. Traditional methods like 'masking' or 'threshold' filtering are often used, but they risk filtering out useful information, especially in regions where the nighttime light radiance of small settlements might be lower than the threshold.

Comparison.Question: How does the patches filtering method (PFM) for separating nighttime lights induced by biomass burning compare to traditional masking or threshold filtering methods in terms of effectiveness for identifying human settlements in northern Equatorial Africa and the Sahel?
Comparison.Answer: The patches filtering method (PFM) developed in the research allows for better separation of unstable nighttime lights induced by biomass burning from stable settlement lights. PFM takes into account the short duration of biomass burning events, effectively separating these signals while retaining the relatively stable lights of small settlements. Traditional methods like masking or threshold filtering might filter out useful information from small settlements due to their lower nighttime light radiance.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in spatial resolution and calibration between NPP-VIIRS nighttime light data and DMSP-OLS data for monitoring human activities in Africa?
Comparison.Answer: NPP-VIIRS data has a higher spatial resolution (about 742 m) compared to DMSP-OLS data and features on-board calibration, which enhances its sensitivity to dim lights and prevents saturation. In contrast, DMSP-OLS has lower spatial and radiometric resolution, limiting its application for detecting small-scale and scattered settlements.

Interpretation.Question: How can the separation of stable and unstable nighttime lights improve the interpretation of human settlement patterns in equatorial Africa?
Interpretation.Answer: The separation of stable nighttime lights, which are associated with settlements, from unstable nighttime lights, caused by biomass burning, can enhance the identification and understanding of human settlement patterns. This method allows researchers to focus on lights that are indicative of human activity, thus providing clearer insights into settlement distributions, especially in regions with small and scattered settlements.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are posed by biomass burning in the interpretation of nighttime light data, and how can these be mitigated to improve data accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: Biomass burning poses a significant challenge as it emits light that can be mistaken for settlement lights in nighttime light data. This can be mitigated by developing methods such as the patches filtering method, which separates biomass burning light from settlement light by considering the short duration of biomass burning events, improving the accuracy of detecting human activities.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the improved spatial and radiometric resolution of NPP-VIIRS data contribute to the interpretation of nighttime light patterns over DMSP-OLS data?
Interpretation.Answer: The improved spatial and radiometric resolution of NPP-VIIRS data allows for better detection and characterization of human settlements, particularly small and dispersed ones, which may not be adequately captured by DMSP-OLS data. This enhances the ability to identify even dim lights associated with small settlements, providing more detailed insights into human activities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in distinguishing between nighttime lights from human settlements and those from biomass burning in data collection?

Biomass burning emits light at night, which can be captured by sensors and cannot be visually distinguished from the light related to settlements in nighttime light data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to capture stable nighttime lights associated with small settlements in northern Equatorial Africa and the Sahel region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty arises because the biomass burning nighttime radiance often exceeds certain thresholds, while the nighttime light radiance of many small settlements might be less, especially in developing regions. Therefore, methods like the 'threshold' filtering inevitably filter out useful information on nighttime light related to human settlements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the limitations faced by earlier datasets like DMSP-OLS in capturing detailed anthropic information compared to NPP-VIIRS?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations of earlier datasets like DMSP-OLS are due to their lower spatial and radiometric resolution, which restrict the application of methods to effectively distinguish and capture detailed anthropic information compared to NPP-VIIRS, which offers higher spatial resolution and on-board calibration.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a filtering method to separate stable nighttime lights from unstable lights due to biomass burning in remote sensing data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a filtering method, such as the patches filtering method (PFM), can lead to improved quality of nighttime light data. It allows for the effective separation of settlement lights from biomass burning lights and captures the seasonality of biomass burning. This results in more accurate identification of small settlements, even in areas with fragmented and unstable power supply.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from employing high-resolution datasets alongside nighttime light data to identify human settlements in sparsely populated regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of high-resolution datasets, such as the Sentinel-2 prototype Land Cover map and high-resolution Google Earth images, with nighttime light data can enhance the capability to identify human settlements. Specifically, it can improve the recognition rate of small settlements and aid in capturing settlements that are 2.5 square kilometers or less, providing a better understanding of human activities in sparsely populated areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of low power penetration on the accuracy of nighttime light data in capturing human activity in northern Equatorial Africa and the Sahel region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Low power penetration in northern Equatorial Africa and the Sahel region affects the accuracy of nighttime light data in capturing human activity. Frequent power cuts and low electricity availability can result in dim nighttime light signals from small settlements. However, improved data processing methods, such as the patches filtering method, can help retain these dim lights and effectively identify settlements, notwithstanding their unstable power supply.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing new methods for filtering nighttime light data in relation to human activities in northern Equatorial Africa and the Sahel?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to improve the ability to identify small settlements, including small and scattered ones, by separating stable nighttime lights associated with settlements from unstable nighttime lights due to biomass burning.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to differentiate between lights from biomass burning and those from human settlements when analyzing nighttime light data in this geographical region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Differentiating between these lights is important because biomass burning emits light at night, which can be captured by sensors and cannot be visually distinguished from settlement lights in nighttime light data, leading to potential misinterpretation of human activity data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of using the patches filtering method (PFM) in processing NPP-VIIRS nighttime light data for this region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using the patches filtering method is to effectively separate unstable nighttime light induced by biomass burning from stable nighttime light associated with human settlements, thereby improving the quality of nighttime light data and enhancing the identification of human settlements, especially in sparsely populated areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be used to differentiate stable nighttime lights associated with human settlements from unstable lights caused by biomass burning in nighttime remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One approach is the patches filtering method (PFM), which separates unstable nighttime light induced by biomass burning from stable nighttime light in NPP-VIIRS monthly nighttime light data. This method considers the relatively short duration of biomass burning events to distinguish them from settlement lights.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in improving the identification of small settlements in satellite-based nighttime light data for regions with low power stability?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves applying a filtering method such as PFM to refine NPP-VIIRS monthly nighttime light data, aiming to separate biomass burning signals from stable settlement lights. This approach enhances the ability to identify small and scattered settlements, especially in regions with unstable power supply.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can auxiliary datasets be integrated to validate and enhance nighttime light data for better detection of human activities in sparsely populated regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Auxiliary datasets such as the Sentinel-2 prototype Land Cover map, global land-cover and land-use reference data from the Geo-Wiki platform, and high-resolution Google Earth images can be used to evaluate and validate the new annual nighttime light images. These sources help assess the effectiveness of detection and improve the identification of human settlements.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the collection of high-resolution nighttime light data in the northern Equatorial Africa and Sahel region?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the National Polar-orbiting Partnership Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (NPP-VIIRS), which offers higher spatial resolution and on-board calibration compared to earlier systems like the DMSP-OLS, enable the collection of high-resolution nighttime light data. This technology is not affected by saturation and has a higher sensitivity to dim light, facilitating the capture of detailed nighttime light information in large areas.

Enablement.Question: How do data collection methods address the challenge of distinguishing between light from human settlements and light from biomass burning in nighttime light data?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection methods address this challenge by employing techniques such as the patches filtering method (PFM), which separates unstable nighttime light induced by biomass burning from stable nighttime light associated with human settlements. This method considers the relatively short duration of biomass burning events to effectively differentiate between the two light sources.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources enable the successful use of nighttime light data to identify small and scattered settlements in regions with unstable power supply?
Enablement.Answer: The successful use of nighttime light data to identify small and scattered settlements is enabled by resources such as high-resolution satellite data from NPP-VIIRS, which provides the necessary spatial detail to capture even dim lights from small settlements. Additionally, the application of refined data processing methods like the patches filtering method (PFM) allows for the separation of human-induced light from other sources, enhancing the data's ability to identify settlements amidst unstable power supply conditions.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might researchers face when using nighttime light data to map human activities in areas with low power penetration?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers face significant challenges in areas with low power penetration due to frequent power cuts, which lead to dim and unstable nighttime lights that are difficult to distinguish from other light sources like biomass burning. This instability complicates the accurate mapping of human activities using nighttime light data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how nighttime light data can be used to distinguish between human settlements and biomass burning in remote sensing.
Assertion.Answer: Nighttime light data from satellite-borne imaging radiometers capture light emitted at night, which can be from human settlements or biomass burning. By using methods like the patches filtering method (PFM), it is possible to separate unstable nighttime light caused by biomass burning from stable light associated with human settlements, considering the short duration of biomass burning events.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges in obtaining accurate nighttime light data in regions with low power penetration and frequent power cuts.
Assertion.Answer: In regions with low power penetration and frequent power cuts, such as northern Equatorial Africa and the Sahel, nighttime light data collection is challenged by unstable electricity supply and the presence of biomass burning. These factors can obscure the signals from human settlements, making it difficult to capture accurate data that reflects true human activity.

Request/Directive.Answer: The biggest obstacle to obtaining images that only retain information about settlements comes from biomass burning. Biomass burning emits light at night, which can be captured by sensors and cannot be visually distinguished in a direct manner from the light related to settlements in nighttime light data. The biomass burning signal is usually separated from the settlement signal by the 'masking' or by the 'threshold' filtering method. Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a novel method used to improve the identification of small settlements in nighttime light data and its effectiveness.
